    Recent Challenges in Indian Democracy

    Nagendra Chatterjee     6 minute read    Read in Hindi   HOME    August 12, 2021   

    The pillars of ‘Democratic Republic’, on which the nation stood are weakened. The democracy is for the people therefore it is responsibility of people to give strength to these weakening pillars.

    Translated from भारतीय लोकतन्त्र की वर्तमान चुनौतियाँ

    As independent nation we are celebrating ‘Amritotsav’ on 75th anniversary of independence. The generation who suffered in pulling the boat of independence to shore had passed away and they are also no more who contributed in the brickwork in erecting the building of democracy. Today the nation is in those hands who neither had the overexcited desire of independence nor suffered the tortures in freedom struggle. Let us examine the appearance of the picture of ambitions and expectations of freedom in the hands of new generation.

    After few days of independence, ‘We the people of India’ together erected the structure of ‘Democratic Republic’ for this ‘Sovereign’ nation. It was hoped that our restless desires in course of centuries long bondage will start taking shape in this structure. The wheels of the chariot of time kept rolling on. In the due course we achieved many milestones, we defeated enemies in many wars, exploded atoms and got listed in atomic nations, stationed space crafts in space orbits, led many international organisations and proudly hoisted the good fortune flag of India on the word map. The enthusiasm filling list of such pride songs is quite long. We have considerable amounts of crises and challenges also. Tottering economy as ‘Democratic Republic’, ill effects of demonetisation and GST, insecurity of women and decreasing number of women workers, highest unemployment in 45 years, any of our educational institutions not among 100 world educational institutions, year after year decrease in registration of children in schools, many thousands of farmers suiciding for problems in agriculture, shameful exposure of health system in Corona and so on, I am not going to discuss many such blazing problems because, most of these are related to administrative and political efficiencies. I want to discuss only those constitutional elements for which this vast nation is established as ‘Democratic Republic’. Yes, this is the constitution which gave the free nation the stature of ‘Democratic Republic’.

    Looking through the windows of history, the transformation of the land mass into an intact nation, is necessary from the view point of republic, equally necessary while going to celebrate ‘Amritotsav’ on 75th anniversary. Recall the chapter of history, when this nation got freedom then, the British Army Commander in Chief, Claud Auchinleck sceptically said, “Punjabi’s are different from Madrasi’s in the same way as the Scottish from the Italian. … it is not possible to make a nation from a subcontinent of many nations.” Instead of many similar prophecies, a new nation was created from many nations, rejecting the prophecies, now celebrating “Amrtotsav” with her head raised like the Himalayas. Instead of all doubts the subcontinent emerged integrated and intact because in the foundation of the new building the first stone was “Bharat that is India is federation of states.” (Constitution of India, part 1, Article 1.1). It became the first sentence in the constitution.

    Apart from many nations as a nation the federal shape of India was the reason for it making a nation from many nations of subcontinent. All regions had separate geographical features, separate cultural identity, and they had the restless feeling of keeping their own geo-cultural unique glories. Hence, they had separate needs. For this reason, with unifying ties with a nation in the areas like land, taxation, education, health, administration, and developing language-culture was given to states. It was thought that as in a large family the respect for all individuals for their personal taste, attitudes and individuality is maintained similarly the unity of the vast nation can be kept by respecting its diversity.

    But, entering the 8th decade of independence the centralist plastering started on the walls of federalism. In agriculture & land, education policy, health provisions, transportation rules, administrative intervention, new devices in tax collections, and in many unorganised projects centralism is dominating. The tendency of overthrowing and forming governments in states by decision of centre was already there from very beginning. One nation one tax, one nation one language, one nation one law, one nation one education may sound appealing slogans. Tendency of centralism is not only the non-compliance with the constitution but, under this plaster the possibility of vocalising the emerging turbulence in regional self-respect is feared. Though this problem has yet not came up seriously, but in collection of taxes the states are facing troubles and the way in which the tension between states and centre is rising it could create a serious challenge in future. This rising tendency of centralism should be considered as big political challenge today in keeping India as integrated nation.

    Recall the words in the preamble of constitution in which, “Socialist, secular, democratic republic guaranteeing all citizens social, economic, political justice, thought, expression, belief, freedom of worship and religion, and providing equal opportunity” was ensured. But in this great republic getting justice is individual responsibility of a victim. Tossing the populist slogan of ‘Social justice’ several states are capable of running uninterrupted rule, but, the assurance of the social justice for the sections of society that resulted in capturing the throne of power did not give anything beyond the political rattle of reservation. Instead, the ‘Social justice’ slogan has worked in widening the social gap. The second challenge today is to fill up the social gap among religious and caste groups for making ‘fraternity to assure unity & integrity of nation’.

    The above quoted words of preamble had served assurance to individual’s freedom inside the nation. This assurance helped the unity of the nation and stopped the fleeing feet. Many steps were also taken to maintain this assurance. It was necessary to secure ‘fraternity for assuring unity and integrity of the nation’, ‘freedom of belief, religion and worship’. But when citizenship is decided on basis of religion, murders on basis of consumed food, lynching on seeing dresses and religious celebration become state celebration, that is to say that in a secular nation the pro-religious programmes and discussions are taking place then the belief from the words of constitution are uprooted.

    Not only the attack on secularism, but state organised movement of stitching all those lips who murmur in favour of humanity, is cause of concern. Means, the third challenge is nation building on the values of secularism, freedom and fraternity to bring back ‘thought, expression, belief, and freedom for religion and worship’ which is beauty of any democracy.

    This nation took the vow of becoming ‘socialist’ nation. But with time the hope for socialism dimmed up. In the past at some moment the end of privy purse, nationalisation of banks and mines were taken as steps in the direction of socialism and now the banks and mines are again getting privatised. Consequence of such course of events is 73% of resources are in the pockets of 1 percent people. The increasing inequality day after day is violating the constitutional provisions and is danger alarm for the country. Stopping the rising inequality is the fourth big challenge.

    The corruption in politics and political corruption – both are big challenges before the country. Where the politics should have the charm to serve people, there is charm for power and money. As a net result, the accepted responsibility of governing ‘for the people’ is becoming the source for the exploitation of the people. Means the Ganga is soiled in descending course. The collaboration of power and capitalist (crony capitalism) has worsened the situation. The collaboration has resulted in the diversion of the path of the stream of state’s power from irrigating the huts towards palaces. The democratic goals are killed by it. Tackling this problem is the fifth big challenge.

    The pillars of ‘Democratic Republic’, on which the nation stood are weakened. The democracy is for the people therefore it is responsibility of people to give strength to these weakening pillars. We should not get engrossed in this ‘Amritotsav’ celebration to such extent that those for whom the celebration is being done, are left behind.
